'M'e Maneo's 
 pumpkin 
 
 Marion Drew 
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day, ’M’e Maneo planted 
 a pumpkin sed. 
 It grew into a very big pumpkin. 
 
 It blocked her garden path. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 ‘M’e Maneo wanted to move the 
 pumpkin. 
 
 She went to her neighbour. 
 “‘M’e Mapalesa,’ she said, “please
 help me to move my pumpkin. It is
 
 blocking my path.” 
 The two ladies pushed and pushed,
 
 but that pumpkin did not move. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 They went to ‘M’e Maselo. 
 “Please help us move ‘M’e Maneo’s 
 pumpkin!” they asked. 
 
 ‘M’e Maselo came to help them. 
 The thre ladies pushed and pushed 
 that pumpkin, but stil it did not move. 
 
 “I don’t know what to do,” said ‘M’e 
 Maneo. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Just then a litle worm came into ‘M’e
 Maneo’s garden. It was hungry. It nibled
 the big pumpkin. 
 
 “Stop,” said the pumpkin. 
 But the litle worm nibled again.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “Stop! You are tickling me,” said the 
 
 pumpkin. “I don’t like it.” 
 And the pumpkin roled away 
 down the hil. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The pumpkin stoped in a field at
 the botom of the hil. Two shepherds
 found it. 
 
 “What shal we do with this pumpkin?”
 they asked. 
 “Let’s eat it,” they said, “it loks
 
 delicious.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 They tok a big stone and tried 
 to break open the pumpkin. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 “No!” cried the pumpkin. 
 The shepherds jumped back. 
 
 The pumpkin began to open. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Out of the pumpkin came a moloi. 
 
 She had one arm, one eye and one leg. 
 She loked terible. 
 “Don’t disturb me,” said the moloi 
 
 in a big voice, “I am the pumpkin chief.” 
 The pumpkin closed again. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The shepherds were very frightened.
 They ran home to tel their parents.
 "Oh! We are so lucky!" said their parents.
 
 "Don’t you know about the pumpkin
 moloi?" 
 "It is a very special pumpkin," said the
 
 shepherds' parents. "You must leave it
 alone." 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 "Next sumer the pumpkin wil open again and the moloi wil scater 
 pumpkin seds al over our vilages. We wil have many, many pumpkins to
 eat," said the shepherd's parents. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 And so it hapened that the next 
 
 sumer, ‘M’e Maneo’s pumpkin burst 
 open. It was ful of many, many seds. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Out came the pumpkin moloi. 
 With her one leg she climbed out
 of the pumpkin. 
 
 With her one eye she loked acros
 al the vilages. 
 With her one arm she threw al 
 
 those seds acros the valey. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 13  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The seds grew into beautiful big 
 pumpkins in al the gardens in the valey. 
 
 That winter everyone in the vilages had 
 lots of pumpkins to eat. 
 They went to ‘M’e Maneo. “Thank you, 
 
 ‘M’e Maneo!” they cried. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 14
